flow.descriptionCdata:
659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.031de3f2-969d-4177-9674-99ba0d01fca9.description=This flow is used to Update Changes. Inputs host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance. Format\: scheme\://domain Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. Default value\: basic Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma. Example\: basic | basic,digest username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request. password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request. apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty. Example\: v1 systemId - The System ID of the of the Change to be updated. Example\: 71c7ac460f811200ff7eb17ce1050e7a requestBody - The string to include in the body of the request, in the format accepted by ServiceNow. In case more Change fields need to be addressed, they can be provided in the "requestBody" input. When a custom body is provided, the values provided in the inputs named "change" will be ignored unless their reference is used in the new body. Example\: {'short_description'\:'Example description','severity'\:'1','assigned_to'\:'46c1293aa9fe1981000dc753e75ebeee','state'\:'4'} changeShortDescription - The short description of the Change, in the form of a string. changeDescription - The description of the Change, in the form of a string. changeNumber - The number of the Change. Should contain the "CHG" prefix followed by 7 or more digits. Example\: CHG0100001 changeRequestedBy - The system ID of the entity that requested the Change. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 changeCategory - The Category name in the form of a string. Example\: Software, Hardware changeConfigurationItem - The system ID of the Configuration Item. (CMDB CI) Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 changePriority - The Priority of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 changeRisk - The risk of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 changeImpact - The impact of the Change, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3 changeApproval - The Approval status in the form of a string. Valid values\: approved, requested, not requested yet, rejected changeType - The type of the Change in the form of a string. Example\: Routine, Comprehensive changeState - The State of the Change, in the form of a positive integer. Each integer represents an Incident State as follows\: 1\=Open, 2\=Work in Progress, 3\=Closed Complete, 4\=Closed Incomplete, 7\=Closed Skipped. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 changeAssignmentGroup - The system ID of the Assignment Group. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 changeAssignedTo - The system ID of the entity to which the Change should be assigned to. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 preemptiveAuth - If this field is 'true' authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is 'false' a request with no authentication info will be made and if server responds with 401 and a header like WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm" only then the authentication info will be sent. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site. proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used. proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy. proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value. trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it. Default value\: false Valid values\: true, false x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option. Default value\: strict Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the 'url') is not 'https' or if trustAllRoots is 'true' this input is ignored. Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS) trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied. Default value\: changeit connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds Examples\: 10, 20 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes). Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route. Default value\: 2 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total. Default value\: 20 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:". Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). Examples\: Accept\:text/plain contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body. Default value\: "" (empty) Examples\: "text/html", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE Default value\: ISO-8859-1 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS. Default value\: ISO-8859-1 Results returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message. document - This will contain the response body. exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception. statusCode - The HTTP status code. Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request) Examples\: 200, 404 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline. Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). Responses success - The operation completed without a runtime exception. failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url). Notes\: 1. The values stored in the fields of the Change will not be changed if the "change" inputs are left empty. 2. The reference of the "change" inputs should be removed from inside the "requestBody" input when they are deleted. 3. When more Change fields are required, than the ones exposed, you can add them as inputs and insert their reference in the Json found in the "requestBody" input. 4. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 4.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer 4.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.0c02eb78-928e-4868-8ae5-9362c15496a5.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.0d43a086-4f24-4ae7-ab0a-0eba49e18cee.callout=Run Vcenter provisioning process 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.1b48d671-f577-4db4-b326-07a72a5fdbd8.prompt=Reboot\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.1ec011de-4175-4b08-93f1-7c0f2f1e8633.description=Scans the given servers for patch policy compliance Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. patchPolicyName - Name of the patch policy serverNames - Server name or search expression patchID - ID of the patch patchType - The type of the patch Responses\: success - retrieved successfully failure - failed to retrieve data 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.1f55dbbc-dcfc-412a-8965-78cb4186f796.description=
Retrieves detailed information about a specific device configuration.

Inputs\:
    coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your NAS core.
    corePort - The port used to connect to your NAS core.
Default value\: 443
    coreProtocol - The protocol used to connect to your NAS core.
Default value\: https
Valid values\: http, https
    coreUsername - The username for the NAS core.
    corePassword - The password for the NAS user.
    id - The configuration's ID for which the details are retrieved.

Results\:
    returnResult - Device configuration (or snapshot) details.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.


Notes\:
1. The configuration's ID can be obtained using the operation "Get Configurations By IP".
2. This operation effectively returns the Device Configuration Detail Page, in text format, which enables you to examine the details of a specific configuration.
659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.27f45338-a43e-409e-badc-6b7aa4faba2d.callout=Close Service Manager Change Request after successful completion / Validation. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.28e66c3e-2201-4b35-8c5c-466d96b0f21b.prompt=Port\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.2bcf07cd-2742-4e9e-8f88-5be661a22b7e.prompt=Enter a value for corePassword 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.2cb23118-6784-4daa-8f37-d4864312671b.prompt=Destination Path\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.438006e0-fabb-4af1-9417-a063dafa88d5.prompt=Port\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.463d414f-53aa-447f-97ff-a4d3919fea32.prompt=Configuration ID\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.4700aeeb-1045-4e86-a229-50bb1b058da0.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.4bb97a17-c285-469b-9def-e18ad4c48116.prompt=Message\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.4f5ba68f-74fe-477f-90dd-57881af0e708.callout=enable active server monitors 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.50f8547a-912f-4993-af49-18eb6d7ae7df.prompt=HostName\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.51af843e-da54-460e-8331-5386b929edb9.prompt=Enable?\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.55f59a49-be52-42c7-89c6-bd513d8ac205.prompt=Destination Path\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.5f840a86-8c37-41c5-9ceb-4ae7f69da727.description=This flow is used to Update Changes. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied. Default value\: changeit connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds Examples\: 10, 20 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes). Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route. Default value\: 2 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total. Default value\: 20 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:". Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). Examples\: Accept\:text/plain contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body. Default value\: "" (empty) Examples\: "text/html", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE Default value\: ISO-8859-1 responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS. Default value\: ISO-8859-1 Results returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message. document - This will contain the response body. exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception. statusCode - The HTTP status code. Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request) Examples\: 200, 404 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url). Notes\: 1. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.65dc5c03-304e-468c-a274-4d6fa551d927.prompt=Timeout (seconds)\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.67f69ce4-976e-46f5-89fc-98065f5da90b.description=This flow is used to Create Incidents. Inputs host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance. Format\: scheme\://domain Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. Default value\: basic Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma. Example\: basic | basic,digest username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request. password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request. apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty. Example\: v1 requestBody - The string to include in the body of the request, in the format accepted by ServiceNow. In case more Incident fields need to be addressed, they can be provided in the "requestBody" input. When a custom body is provided, the values provided in the inputs named "incident" will be ignored unless their reference is used in the new body. Example\: {'short_description'\:'Example description','severity'\:'1','assigned_to'\:'46c1293aa9fe1981000dc753e75ebeee','state'\:'4'} incidentShortDescription - The short description of the Incident to be created, in the form of a string. If this input is left empty, the short description of the created Incident will be empty. incidentNumber - The number of the Incident to be created. Should contain the "INC" prefix followed by 7 or more digits. If this input is left empty, ServiceNow will automatically assign a number. Example\: INC0100001 incidentCaller - The system ID of the Caller. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 incidentLocation - The system ID of the Location. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 incidentCategory - The Category name in the form of a string. Example\: Software, Inquiry / Help incidentSubcategory - The Subcategory name in the form of a string. Example\: Email, Operating System incidentImpact - The Impact of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3 incidentUrgency - The Urgency of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 3. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3 incidentPriority - The Priority of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 5. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 incidentOpenedBy - The system ID of the entity that submitted the Incident. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 incidentContactType - The Contact Type in the form of a string. Example\: Phone, Email incidentState - The State of the Incident, in the form of a positive integer between 1 and 7. Each integer represents an Incident State as follows\: 1\=New, 2\=Active, 3\=Awaiting Problem, 4\=Awaiting User Info, 5\=Awaiting Evidence, 6\=Resolved, 7\=Closed. Valid values\: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 incidentAssignmentGroup - The system ID of the Assignment Group. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 incidentAssignedTo - The system ID of the entity to which the Incident should be assigned to. Example\: 60792105db65120058d5788dbf961978 preemptiveAuth - If this field is "true", authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is "false" a request with no authentication info will be made and if the server responds with 401 and a header such as WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm", only then will the authentication info be sent. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site. proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used. proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy. proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value. trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it. Default value\: false Valid values\: true, false x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker (Man-In-The-Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option. Default value\: strict Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the URL) is not HTTPS or if trustAllRoots is "true" this input is ignored. Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS) trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied. Default value\: changeit connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds Examples\: 10, 20 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of 0 represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes). Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route. Default value\: 2 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total. Default value\: 20 headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:". Format\: According to HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). Examples\: Accept\:text/plain responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS. Default value\: ISO-8859-1 followRedirects - Specifies whether the HTTP client automatically follows redirects. Redirects explicitly prohibited by the HTTP specification as requiring user intervention will not be followed (redirects on POST and PUT requests that are converted to GET requests). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false requestCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP request body. If contentType is empty, the requestCharacterSet will use the default value. If contentType will include charset (ex.\: "application/json; charset\=UTF-8"), the requestCharacterSet value will overwrite the charset value from contentType input. This should not be provided for method\=GET, HEAD, TRACE Default value\: ISO-8859-1 Results\: returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message. document - This will contain the response body. exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception. statusCode - The HTTP status code. Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request) Examples\: 200, 404 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline. Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). systemId - The system ID of the created Incident. Responses success - The operation completed without a runtime exception. failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url). Notes\: 1. The reference of the "incident" inputs should be removed from inside the "requestBody" input when they are deleted. 2. When more Incident fields are required, than the ones exposed, you can add them as inputs and insert their reference in the Json found in the "requestBody" input. 3. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 3.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer 3.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.69327174-c65a-4ec1-8481-277b40803832.description=
Enables or disables a SiteScope monitor

Inputs\:
    hostname - The DNS name or IP Address of your SiteScope host.
    port - The port to connect to your SiteScope host on.
    protocol - The protocol to connect to your SiteScope host with (HTTP or HTTPS).  HTTPS is not configured by default during SiteScope install.
    username - The username for the SiteScope host.
    password - The password for the SiteScope user.
    monitorPath - Monitor path (eg. Monitors\WSMonitor). If seen in the UI, do not include the "SiteScope" root folder.
    enable - Yes enable the monitor. No disables the monitor.
    disablePeriod - If disabling, time period to disable (seconds). Use 0 or leave empty to disable indefinitely.
    delimiter - The delimiter for the monitorPath.
    keyStore - The path to the KeyStore file. This file should contain a certificate the client is capable of authenticate with on the Sitescope server.
    keyStorePassword - The password associated with the KeyStore file.
    trustStore - The path to the Java TrustStore file. This file should contain the Sitescope server certificates.
    trustStorePassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file.
	
Note\: The input delimiter is optional. If the name of the monitor to enable itself includes "\" or "/", then specify a different delimiter.
(eg. If the name of the monitor is "monitor\test", then specify a delimiter as an input. In this case the monitor path should be given as (eg\:parentGroup\:childGroup\:monitor\test).
Here the delimiter would be "\:"). Also you can specify a delimiter, if you want it to be other than the default one ("\" or "/").

Responses\:
success - The operation completed successfully.
failure - Something went wrong.

Returns\:
returnResult - Result of the operation

Note\:
The SiteScope server can be hardened by following the instructions in the SiteScope Deployment Guide, "Running SiteScope Securely" section.
When a hardened SiteScope server is used as a target, authentication is made with the keystore file ( which contains the client certificate ) and the trustStore file ( which contains the server certificate ), along with the corresponding passwords.
In addition to providing the keyStore and trustStore inputs, the username must have the value of "SITESCOPE_CERTIFICATE_AUTHENTICATED_USER". The password input is ignored.
659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.6f62caf7-8ab6-4f41-b8e9-faacdca8770c.callout=Stage 2\: Disable Server Monitors 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.7235b94e-d4c8-451c-a8d8-735f53469eb8.description=Attaches a software policy to a list of servers. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. policyName - The name of the policy to attach. policyID - The ID of the policy to attach. If this input is provided, then 'policyName' is ignored. attachableName - The names, separated by 'separator', of the attachable objects to attach the policy to. attachableID - The IDs, separated by 'separator', of the attachable objects to attach the policy to. If this input is provided, then 'attachableName' is ignored. attachableType - The type of the attachable objects (all must be of the same type). Can be\: SERVER, DEVICE_GROUP, HYPERVISOR. separator - The separator used for separating the inputs. The default value for the separator is comma (,). Responses\: success - The operation completed successfully. failure - Something went wrong. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.782b7862-dd7f-4f20-9556-a9a7289e7eb6.prompt=Host\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.7b143d21-53f9-490c-bc78-3268e848a341.description=Start a software policy compliance scan for the given server. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. serverName - The name or the search expression for the server serverID - The ID of the server. If provided, the 'serverName' will be ignored. Responses\: success - retrieved successfully failure - failed to retrieve data Returns\: id - The unique ID of this object. description - The description of this object. blockedReason - The reason why this job is blocked. cancelledReason - The reason why this job is canceled. endDate - The date at which this job will cease to run. notificationFailureOwner - The user who will own this job if it fails. notificationSuccessOwner - The user who will own this job if it completes. notificationFailureRecipients - A ; delimited list of users who will receive notification if this job fails. notificationSuccessRecipients - A ; delimited list of users who will receive notification if this job completes. serverName - The name of the server associated with this job. serverId - The id of the server associated with this job. staleDate - The date after which this job is considered stale. startDate - The date where this job started. status - This object's status. username - This object's user name. userTag - This object's unique user tag. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.7e4c3ef7-65a4-4a4a-b7cd-cbba439f2d6c.prompt=Enter a value for coreUsername 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.80a509a4-d2f3-46a4-8329-24831413178a.description= Inputs\: host - vCenter DNS name/IP Address username - vCenter user password - vCenter user password port - vCenter port protocol - vCenter protocol hypervisorName - Hypervisor DNS name/IP Address dataStore - Datastore of the hypervior datacenterName - Datacenter name hostname - VM Server name templateReference - VM Template name osType - OS Type of the template CPUs - CPU Count to be assigned Memory - Memory Size to be assigned Results\: vmId - VM Identifies of the created VM ipAddress - IP Address of the created VM macAddress - MAC Address of the created VM 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.8336e801-9b83-458a-80d9-40decd546a31.description=Starts a remediation on the given server using a set of attached/detached software policies. If the software policies information is not provided, then a full software policy remediation is performed. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. serverName - The names of the servers to remediate (separated by 'separator'). serverId - The IDs of the servers to remediate (separated by 'separator'). If provided, the 'serverName' is ignored. softwarePoliciesNames - The names of the software policies to remediate against (separated by 'separator'). The software policies need to be attached/detached to/from the server before the remediation takes place. softwarePoliciesIDs - The IDs of the software policies to remediate against (separated by 'separator'). The software policies need to be attached/detached to/from the server before the remediation takes place. If this input is provided, then 'softwarePoliciesNames' is ignored. wait - An integer value specifying how many milliseconds should be waited for the job to finish. If not specified the job is started, but may not have finished. rebootOption - Reboot Option for Remediating a server. It could be one of [suppress, per_action, at_end] or it can be left blank. Where\: - suppress - Suppress all reboots; - per_action - Reboot after each installation or uninstallation; - at_end - Reboot at the end of remediation; - left blank (no value provided) - Reboot as specified by individual software items. Responses\: success - The operation completed successfully. failure - Something went wrong. Returns\: returnResult - The id of the created job. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.83da9bb6-3d5b-4271-994b-89b33f457aed.callout=Verify / Approve 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.862204e1-410d-483e-9689-665f021e1ad3.description=Starts a job that pushes an application configuration instance for a given sets of targets. NOTE\: For SA 9, at least one of the following inputs should be filled\: 'notificationSuccessRecipients', 'notificationFailureRecipients'. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. targetNames - The list of names of the targets for the application configuration (seaprated by the input 'separator'). targetIDs - The list of IDs of the targets for the application configuration (seaprated by the input 'separator'). targetsType - The type of the targets. Can be\: SERVER, DEVICE_GROUP, HYPERVISOR. applicationInstanceName - The name of the application configuration instance. notificationSuccessOwner - The email address of the owner of this job when it succeeds. notificationSuccessRecipients - The email addresses(comma separated) of the recipients to notify when this job succeeds. notificationFailureOwner - The email address of the owner of this job when it fails. notificationFailureRecipients - The email addresses(comma separated) of the recipients to notify when this job fails. notificationCancelOwner - The email address of the owner of this job when it is canceled. This input is ignored for SA 9. notificationCancelRecipients - The email addresses(comma separated) of the recipients to notify when this job is canceled. This input is ignored for SA 9. separator - The separator used for separating the inputs in the lists\: 'targetNames', 'targetIDs', 'notificationSuccessRecipients', 'notificationFailureRecipients' and 'notificationCancelRecipients'. Its default value is ','. Responses\: success - The operation completed successfully. failure - Something went wrong. Returns\: returnResult - The id of the job created for pushing the application configuration. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.881f548d-2c2c-4569-b09c-9ee9ebbf2e8f.description=Scans the given server for software policy compliance Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. policyName - Name of the software policy serverName - Server name or search expression Responses\: success - retrieved successfully failure - failed to retrieve data 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.8b6e1a1d-0fd2-4fb8-9af7-1c85381a2c75.prompt=Enter a value for coreHost 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.8eaae367-5f5c-4053-bae4-2836044999be.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.930826f5-dd54-408e-bc02-1524ce15c8e1.prompt=Enter a value for policyName 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.939d8d17-41b5-4329-b002-a5542cbd459e.prompt=Username\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.972cb8e1-c3f4-4f1f-aab8-59fa10fb7394.callout=Update Service Manager Change Request with relevant information 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.a27bc47a-25d6-4ce3-af73-3c2beafc110b.callout=Step 7\: Update and Close Service Request 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.a4777052-42b0-4585-9e8c-bf07fe033d05.prompt=Password\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.ab137be7-0da3-4c4e-bbd9-daca185f2a15.callout=Stage 5\: Enable Server Monitors 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.acc8c0c1-7d77-4e58-894a-e40b92a9a557.callout=Create Incident in Service manager following any failures that may have occurred during the provisioning process 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.ad1c6548-9390-4e3f-9d51-2cc5d2998e01.description=Scans the given servers for patch policy compliance Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. patchPolicyName - Name of the patch policy serverNames - Server name or search expression patchID - ID of the patch patchType - The type of the patch Responses\: success - retrieved successfully failure - failed to retrieve data 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.b061bc27-7dc7-488a-a619-4714f31497d0.prompt=Forcibly Close\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.baab8271-bf30-452b-abc3-9519e672f4f8.prompt=Enable?\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.c063172b-edfe-4a1c-86fb-cbcfe07f9612.prompt=Host\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.cd769098-eb15-49c2-9819-093636bd6873.callout=Get Change Request details from Servie Manager 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.d03b23ed-e06e-4e90-a4ff-d4f36648207c.prompt=Protocol\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.d1e853bc-03f1-4421-9df2-ba788b049435.description=This flow is used to retrieve the details of one or more Changes. Inputs host - The URL of the ServiceNow instance. Format\: scheme\://domain Example\: https\://dev10000.service-now.com authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server. The authentication is not preemptive\: a plain request not including authentication info will be made and only when the server responds with a 'WWW-Authenticate' header the client will send required headers. If the server needs no authentication but you specify one in this input the request will work nevertheless. The client cannot choose the authentication method and there is no fallback so you have to know which one you need. If the web application and proxy use different authentication types, these must be specified like in the Example model. Default value\: basic Valid values\: basic, digest, ntlm, kerberos, any, anonymous, "" or a list of valid values separated by comma. Example\: basic | basic,digest apiVersion - The API version with which the request will be sent. The call will be made using the latest API version when this input is left empty. Example\: v1 systemId - The System ID of the Change for which details should be returned. When this imput is left empty, the flow returns the details of multiple iChanges based on the values assigned to the "sysParamLimi", "sysParamQuery" and "sysParamFields" inputs. Example\: 71c7ac460f811200ff7eb17ce1050e7a username - The ServiceNow username used to perform the request. password - The ServiceNow password used to perform the request. sysParamLimit - The maximum number of results to be returned. Default value\: 10000 sysParamQuery - A query string used to filter the results. Example\: urgency\=1 sysParamFields - A query string used to filter the fields returned in the results. Example\: short_description,number,sys_id preemptiveAuth - If this field is 'true' authentication info will be sent in the first request. If this is 'false' a request with no authentication info will be made and if server responds with 401 and a header like WWW-Authenticate\: Basic realm\="myRealm" only then the authentication info will be sent. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the web site. proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default value\: 8080. Valid values\: -1, and positive integer values. When the value is '-1' the default port of the scheme, specified in the 'proxyHost', will be used. proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy. proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value. trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL/TSL. A certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it. Default value\: false Valid values\: true, false x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option. Default value\: strict Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all trustKeystore - The pathname of the Java TrustStore file. This contains certificates from other parties that you expect to communicate with, or from Certificate Authorities that you trust to identify other parties. If the protocol (specified by the 'url') is not 'https' or if trustAllRoots is 'true' this input is ignored. Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts Format\: Java KeyStore (JKS) trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If trustAllRoots is false and trustKeystore is empty, trustPassword default will be supplied. Default value\: changeit connectTimeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in seconds. A timeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds Examples\: 10, 20 socketTimeout - The timeout for waiting for data (a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets), in seconds. A socketTimeout value of '0' represents an infinite timeout. Default value\: 0 Format\: an integer representing seconds useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls in a serializable session object therefore they will be available on a branch level (same subflow, same lane). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: true Valid values\: true,false keepAlive - Specifies whether to create a shared connection that will be used in subsequent calls. If keepAlive is false, the already open connection will be used and after execution it will close it. The operation will use a connection pool stored in a GlobalSessionObject that will be available throughout the execution (the flow and subflows, between parallel split lanes). Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false connectionsMaxPerRoute - The maximum limit of connections on a per route basis. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections per given route. Default value\: 2 connectionsMaxTotal - The maximum limit of connections in total. The default will create no more than 2 concurrent connections in total. Default value\: 20 followRedirects - Specifies whether the HTTP client automatically follows redirects. Redirects explicitly prohibited by the HTTP specification as requiring user intervention will not be followed (redirects on POST and PUT requests that are converted to GET requests). If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: true Valid values\: true, false headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:". Format\: Conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). Examples\: Accept\:text/plain responseCharacterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP response. If responseCharacterSet is empty, the charset from the 'Content-Type' HTTP response header will be used. If responseCharacterSet is empty and the charset from the HTTP response Content-Type header is empty, the default value will be used. You should not use this for method\=HEAD or OPTIONS. Default value\: ISO-8859-1 queryParams - The list containing query parameters to append to the URL. The names and the values must not be URL encoded unless you specify "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=true because if they are encoded and "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=false they will get double encoded. The separator between name-value pairs is "&". The query name will be separated from query value by "\=". Note that you need to URL encode at least "&" to "%26" and "\=" to "%3D" and set "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\="true" if you leave the other special URL characters unencoded they will be encoded by the HTTP Client. Examples\: sysparm_limit\=10&sysparm_query\=severity\=1&sysparm_fields\=short_description,number,sys_id queryParamsAreURLEncoded - Specifies whether to encode (according to the url encoding standard) the queryParams. If you set "queryParamsAreURLEncoded"\=true and you have invalid characters in 'queryParams' they will get encoded anyway. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used. Default value\: false Valid values\: true, false queryParamsAreFormEncoded - Specifies whether to encode the queryParams in the the default format used by the apache http client library - form format. If this input is true then all characters will be encoded based on the queryParamsAreURLEncoded input.If queryParamsAreFormEncoded\=false all reserved chars are not encoded no matter of queryParamsAreURLEncoded input.The only exceptions are for space(' ')character which is encoded as %20 and + (plus) which is encoded as %20 and not encoded if queryParamsAreURLEncoded\=false. Check the "v2.0" folder description for more details. Default value\: true. Valid values\: true, false Example\: query\=test te%20@st will be encoded in query\=test%20te%20@st Results returnResult - This will contain the response entity. In case of an error this output will contain the error message. document - This will contain the response body. exception - In case of success response, this result is empty. In case of failure response, this result contains the java stack trace of the runtime exception. statusCode - The HTTP status code. Format\: 1xx (Informational - Request received, continuing process), 2xx (Success - The action was successfully received, understood, and accepted), 3xx (Redirection - Further action must be taken in order to complete the request), 4xx (Client Error - The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled), 5xx Server Error - The server failed to fulfil an apparently valid request) Examples\: 200, 404 responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline. Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616). systemIdList - In case the response entity contains system IDs, they will be displayed in this result, in the form of a list. Responses success - The operation completed without a runtime exception. failure - A runtime exception occurred. This may be due to incorrectly formated inputs (headers, proxy, queryParams, url). Notes\: 1. In order to authenticate using an OAuth token\: 1.1. The headers input should contain the following header\: Authorization\:Bearer 1.2. The username and password inputs should remain empty. 2. When the "queryParams" input is specified, the values entered in the "sysParamLimit", "sysParamQuery" and "sysParamFields" inputs are ignored. 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.d308c91f-153f-45f7-9ecd-f79eaf6fd52b.description=
Initiates a windows shutdown/restart

Authentication note\: The credentials used must be able to log on to both the machine running the Windows RAS, and the host being restarted. If you get a user impersonation failed error, than the user cannot log onto the Windows RAS machine. If you get an access denied error they do not have adequate permissions on the host you are trying to restart.

Inputs\:
host - Hostname of the system to shutdown/restart.
message - Message to show to users connected to the system and to log to the event log.
timeout - The amount of time in seconds to wait before initiating shutdown/restart.
force - (true, false) Force applications to close.
reboot - (true, false) Whether or not to reboot the system.
altuser - Username to use for thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
altpass - Password of the user.

Responses\:
success - System shutdown initiated successfully.
failure - Unable to initiate system shutdown.
659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.d37f3de4-f92a-4a9f-bf29-512576048ca1.callout=Step 6\: Software | Patch Compliance Checks 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.dc954243-df1d-4eba-9cb7-fdc8a58203b4.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.e481ffae-c857-4e1e-9d23-3f3e9c276d99.callout=Stage 3\: Software Installation | Configuration 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.e5745135-32de-4321-ab29-da2fc2c07454.prompt=NAS Core\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.e99f579e-885f-4472-8c97-c70fe4122608.prompt=Protocol\: 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.f1644a44-354e-4c23-a391-0a2bb2ed4f70.callout=Disable active server monitors 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.f3246d48-5f5d-48d6-a369-d584c53ff5f9.description=
Enables or disables a SiteScope monitor

Inputs\:
    hostname - The DNS name or IP Address of your SiteScope host.
    port - The port to connect to your SiteScope host on.
    protocol - The protocol to connect to your SiteScope host with (HTTP or HTTPS).  HTTPS is not configured by default during SiteScope install.
    username - The username for the SiteScope host.
    password - The password for the SiteScope user.
    monitorPath - Monitor path (eg. Monitors\WSMonitor). If seen in the UI, do not include the "SiteScope" root folder.
    enable - Yes enable the monitor. No disables the monitor.
    disablePeriod - If disabling, time period to disable (seconds). Use 0 or leave empty to disable indefinitely.
    delimiter - The delimiter for the monitorPath.
    keyStore - The path to the KeyStore file. This file should contain a certificate the client is capable of authenticate with on the Sitescope server.
    keyStorePassword - The password associated with the KeyStore file.
    trustStore - The path to the Java TrustStore file. This file should contain the Sitescope server certificates.
    trustStorePassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file.
	
Note\: The input delimiter is optional. If the name of the monitor to enable itself includes "\" or "/", then specify a different delimiter.
(eg. If the name of the monitor is "monitor\test", then specify a delimiter as an input. In this case the monitor path should be given as (eg\:parentGroup\:childGroup\:monitor\test).
Here the delimiter would be "\:"). Also you can specify a delimiter, if you want it to be other than the default one ("\" or "/").

Responses\:
success - The operation completed successfully.
failure - Something went wrong.

Returns\:
returnResult - Result of the operation

Note\:
The SiteScope server can be hardened by following the instructions in the SiteScope Deployment Guide, "Running SiteScope Securely" section.
When a hardened SiteScope server is used as a target, authentication is made with the keystore file ( which contains the client certificate ) and the trustStore file ( which contains the server certificate ), along with the corresponding passwords.
In addition to providing the keyStore and trustStore inputs, the username must have the value of "SITESCOPE_CERTIFICATE_AUTHENTICATED_USER". The password input is ignored.
659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.f65efcfc-ed20-450c-8ecf-ec5a62f4623e.callout=Stage 1\: Server request | Approval | Server provisioning 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.f94bc459-7de5-4186-a81d-c04b5777c8d7.callout=Stage 4\: OS Patch Installation 659ef6cf-f388-4fa3-8279-c42038e44540.ff93e651-9215-4ca5-9dcb-f9a6feb601ba.callout=Post Configuration checks - Software installations, Server Hardening, Compliance checks
flow.name: Server Provisioning

step.name: Scan and Get Software Policy Compliance
